Introduction
My colleagues and I are interested to understand the main factors that affect the maintenance of local arthropod biodiversity in tropical rainforests. We have studied insect-plant interactions, the host-specificity of insect herbivores and interaction networks in tropical rainforests. However, we are now increasingly focusing on the threats to tropical insects induced by global climate change. Please see our new web site at https://striresearch.si.edu/yves-basset-lab/

Projects

Projects (5)
Thermal and Desiccation Tolerance of Tropical Insects
Project
Climate change represents a leading cause of species decline. In Central America, temperature is predicted to rise, and extreme weather events to become more frequent. Tropical insects are especially sensitive to changes in climate; they have a narrower thermal tolerance and lower dispersal ability compared to temperate species. Hence climate change might have wider reaching consequences in tropical regions. Insects form an integral part of ecosystems, a small change in their communities can have ecosystem-wide impacts. Accumulating evidence points towards a widespread collapse of insect populations. We know very little about how insects are likely to respond to climate change and it is unknown how tolerance to environmental perturbations varies between different life stages in tropical ecosystems. We are discerning how thermal and desiccation tolerance of Lepidoptera varies with ontogeny, life-history strategy, and morphology on Barro Colorado Island (BCI), Panama. We are determining the thermal breadth of adult butterflies and are measuring the critical thermal minimum and critical thermal maximum of moths and butterflies at different humidity regimes. The data compiled in this study will be used to refine functional group classifications. It will be combined with the ForestGEO Arthropod Initiative dataset, an exceptional 11-year time-series of Lepidoptera abundance and diversity on BCI, to develop time-series predictive models of the BCI Lepidoptera community.
View
Using field-based entomological research to promote awareness about forest ecosystem conservation
Project
Entomology offers many options by using insects as an educational model in conservation, such as the study of specific functional groups responsible for crucial ecosystems services. Understanding trophic interactions, such as between plant and herbivorous insect, and ecosystem functioning represents an important cognitive knowledge base for increasing awareness of their local environment and conserving their natural habitats. We are encouraging scientists in biodiversity research to share their expertise and participate actively, collaborating with local biological education programs, to increase essential knowledge in ecology and promote awareness about ecosystem conservation.
